> 
> We may not like it, but they have no obligation to announce things the way that we would find most enjoyable.
> It's probably going to be a better ride for us if we accept that SQUAD is really who's in the pilot's seat and try to enjoy the ride, rather than being back-seat drivers pilots.
> 
> I know I don't want to spend the next ten days being angry and frustrated.
> 
> Happy landings!

Or we can use assets like this forum, or reddit, to consolidate Squad's statements for the benefit of fellow customers with lives outside KSP. I don't give one iota for marketing or Squad's hype machine. I'm a self-interested consumer who doesn't want to spend hours trawling through social media to learn in which direction Squad is taking one of my favorite games. For any other developer I would simply bookmark the official news outlet. For KSP I bookmark this forum and reddit, relying on the community to again do what Squad opts to not.

> 
> I think it's more complex than that. I'm not a marketing person, but it seems to me that many marketing campaigns begin with small cryptic teasers of some sort.
> A medium like Twooter is well suited for dropping a small, potentially cryptic, remark which gets people thinking, wondering, guessing.
> 
> A medium like the forum, which is essentially dialogue based, may not be well suited for such an objective.
> 
> We may not like it, but they have no obligation to announce things the way that we would find most enjoyable.
> 
> It's probably going to be a better ride for us if we accept that SQUAD is really who's in the pilot's seat and try to enjoy the ride, rather than being back-seat drivers pilots.
> 
> I know I don't want to spend the next ten days being angry and frustrated.
> 
> Happy landings!

Here's the catch, though. They are obligated to make us happy, because we pay the bills. I don't think Squad are yet to the point where they're to big to fail. Creating a poor reputation with fans can have a negative impact on your profits.

Sadly, I feel like we've become a society that has become willing to settle for the bare minimum from the companies we support. No matter how much we complain, we never actually vote with our dollar. We still see the new Transformers movie. We buy this years Madden, despite the minimal change. My money is worth more than that.

So, here's the rub. I've already payed Squad. So, essentially, they're betting that any negative press I build will be less than negligible.

This was more of a rambling post. I can probably express this better. ...but I'm just now having my morning coffee.

This thread needs a few of these:

![PvD0ofh.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/PvD0ofh.jpg)

Forums such as this have historically been little more than hotbeds for vitriolic posts which frequently derail announcements. Twitter is becoming the new go-to place for several "game studios" to interact with their audience. 

Even if you personally don't like twitter, being an obnoxious twit (pun totally intended) about it is not likely to inspire squad to listen.

> 
> Here's the catch, though. They are obligated to make us happy, because we pay the bills.

I think this is incorrect. As you point out later in your post, you have already paid for the game.

> 
> Sadly, I feel like we've become a society that has become willing to settle for the bare minimum from the companies we support. No matter how much we complain, we never actually vote with our dollar.

I would say that the way our commerce is structured has much more impact than any aggregate choice to 'settle for the bare minimum'.

It seems to me that the concept of 'voting with your dollar' is pretty political/ideological.

> 
> So, here's the rub. I've already payed Squad. So, essentially, they're betting that any negative press I build will be less than negligible.

I'm afraid that I think that is probably a sound marketing strategy. They are proactively building hype for the launch. There will always be some disgruntled owners of any product. It's probably more profitable/cost effective for them to be spending their time on hyping the launch than on 'regruntling' the disgruntled customer.

Happy landings!

p.s. I apologize for the amount of real life that crept into this post.

It's amazing how much angst can be generated by a single tweet.

Attracting new customers is absolutely part of marketing.

So is maintaining goodwill and satisfaction with existing customers.

A good/smart company, IMO, does both.

"We already got your money, so you don't matter" is not a message you want to be sending to customers, ever. Word-of-mouth can kill you there.

Note that I'm not arguing, as some have, that SQUAD should abandon efforts to attract new customers (e.g., with videos) and devote those resources to the game. I'm saying they should do *both*, and keep the community informed through all available channels.
